Replacing all taxes with retail tax seems like a bad idea because:
 
 1: It severly limits the governments ability to adjust the economy to counter implications of financial cycles. As the monetary option has been done away with (for good reasons) the government only has financial politics to play with.
 
 2: A retail tax does not contain any automatic stabilizing qualities. Automatic stabilizing qualities can be found in income and labour baswed taxes as it cools of an overheated labour market.
 
 3: The retail tax is basicly regressive, making the rich pay less than the poor. Even though there are rebates, these seems far to small to change the fact that the retail tax is inherrantly regressive.
 
 4: While it would eliminate some tax evasion, it would encourage others. The argument that it would ellimnate all tax evasion is ludicrus. Evasion from retail tax also creates black markets. Something that often carries external costs.
 
 5: It would tax governmental transfers and incomes deriving from labour or capital alike, forcing the government to increase transfers to maintain the current distribution levels.
 
 6: I don`t understand how the tax pressure could be lowered because of the implementation of the so called "fair-tax" as the advocates never explain any dynamic advantages of the system and I don`t know wether the nubers listed are correct. To me it seems like a hoax, or even prank (the wording on the pages also supports this...).
 
 I can probably think of more reasons why the retail tax is a bad idea, but I have to go and buy groceries now ;)

To be able to actually apply the lessons learned from history, we need to have an economic theory that can explain what happened in the past. And sadly, economists are not very good at using theory. Instead, they rely very much on empirical observations and make generalisations out of them. Problem with this is that empirism cannot explain those institutions and forces that cannot be observed through direct observation. It also makes the explanations rather static and hard to apply to the future. Now, don`t get me wrong.  Economists can predict and explain with various accuracy the consequences of certain actions and events. This prediction and explanation can often vary, depending on which school of thought the economist hails from. It also varies between different individual economists. However, certain basic assumptions, explenations and predictions are more or less based on consensus. After I have heard the explanation or prediction, it is up to me as an individual to judge how I should view the (predicted or explained) consequences. Economic theory lack normative explaining power. Am I to value equality more than economic efficiency? Am I to value economic freedom more than higher returns on capital investments? Am I too value higher wages more than lower inflation? etc, etc. On top of this, economic theory seldom succeeds in quantifying its explanations and prediction.
